awd_titl_txt: Boundaries of Hyperbolic and Relatively Hyperbolic Groups
awd_abstract_narration:
The concept of a group appears in several areas of pure and applied mathematics. Often a group has a topological space, its "boundary at infinity", that gives us some information about the group. The study of this brings the fields of topology, algebra, and dynamics into play. This project addresses the broad question of how much the boundary of a group determines the group.  The principal investigator continually seeks to spread mathematical knowledge to a wide audience, including under-represented groups in mathematics and people working in industry and technology.  This is done through speaking at and organizing conferences in a wide variety of venues aimed at wide audiences, and encouraging people in these groups (including industry)  to attend her classes.  In addition, all of the PI's mathematical results and findings are freely available to the public. 

The project addresses important and fundamental problems involving which hyperbolic or relatively hyperbolic groups can have certain boundaries. For one part of the project the principal investigator plans to extend known results about hyperbolic groups with planar or two-sphere boundaries to the relatively hyperbolic case, strengthening the connection with Kleinian groups and the fundamental groups of 3-manifolds.  The proof methods sometimes are similar to the case of hyperbolic groups but often require different techniques. For the other part of the project she is exploring the wealth of planar boundaries than can occur as the complement of round disks in the 2-sphere.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit: The PI investigated the boundaries of hyperbolic and relatively hyperbolic groups.  The boundary of a group is a topological space that encodes  the ways that sequences in the group can go to infinity.  For example, the boundary of the group of integers is two points. The boundary can be quite complicated and often tells us very usefull information about the group. The PI also studied coherence of groups.  A group is coherent if every finitely generated subgroup is finitely presented. The PI completed 5 papers during this time which emerged from the grant proposal. 

  • Tshishiku, Bena and Walsh, Genevieve. On groups with $S^2$ Bowditch boundary.  Groups, Geometry, and Dynamics. 14  (3) 791-811 (2020).

  • P. Dani, M. Haulmark, and G. S. Walsh, Right-angled Coxeter groups with non-planar boundary, to appear, Groups Geometry and Dynamics. arXiv:1902.01029.

  • S.-H. Kim and G. S. Walsh, ``Some groups with planar boundaries", to appear, Journal of Differential Geometry (special issue). 

  • "Incoherence and fibering of many free-by-free groups" by Robert Kropholler and Genevieve Walsh, to appear in L'Annals d'Institute Fourier.

  • Planar boundaries and parabolic subgroups, arXiv:2008.07639, Submitted.

Broader Impacts:

I have been very active within the larger community over the grant period. I was a co-organizer for six events: An AMS special session at the joint math meetings in 2018, a large conference at CIRM Luminy, France Structure of 3-manifold groups, a Summer school for graduate students at CIRM, 3-manifolds and Geometric Group Theory, a small research conference at CIRM Boundaries of Groups, a workshop at the Institute of Advanced Study Coherence and Quasi-convex subgroups, and a conference at Tufts Groups and Geometry at Tufts.  At all these events, I worked to create an inclusive atmosphere and structure that was welcoming to new mathematicians, non-traditional mathematicians, and mathematicians and scientists from other fields. Over the grant period, I gave over 20 talks, in diverse settings such as at the Institute of Mathematics in Warsaw, Poland, at the IHES in Paris, France, and at a research conference in Nahsolim, Israel. I also spoke as part of a Mathematical Frontiers webinar, aimed at the broader scientific community, and organized by the National Academies of Sciences, Engineering and Medicine. In addition, I am co-editing a book with Luisa Paoluzzi, which is a compilation of mostly survey articles as a proceedings of the Chair Morlet Semester Spring 2018. I am also writing a survey article for that compilation based on my lectures given at the school. I had 2 graduate students obtain their PhDs during the grant period. One has a postdoctoral position and another is working in industry. I now have two new PhD students. I hope that my outreach efforts over the past few years have illuminated mathematics for mathematicians inside and outside of the field, and brought more people into closer contact with math.


Last Modified: 10/15/2021
Modified by: Genevieve S Walsh

Image
  • The boundary can sometimes be realized as a tree of spaces, which is helpful for analysis.
    Picture by Bena Tshishiku. Appears in Tshishiku-Walsh
    Public Domain
    Genevieve S Walsh
